title: Example ChASM Analysis Using Example Data
text: RChASM method identifying chromosomal aneuploidies studies coverage low (0.006X-0.0014X), ancient DNA. RChASM modeling proportion reads mapping chromosome, using Dirichlet-multinomial distribution, estimated user-provided training data set. means RChASM applicable studies least 23 samples. Dirichlet-multinomial Bayesian combination Dirichlet distribution Multinomial distribution. combination two distributions following things: Multinomial distribution: allows us account variability observed proportions due simply sampling depth, measured total number reads mapped reference distribution, given sample. Dirichlet distribution: allows us model variability observed proportions due differences sample degradation data generation protocols. allow different data-generation protocols (called simply “protocol” ), defined combination sequencing types (e.g. shotgun 1240k capture) library preparation/architecture (e.g. single double strand). However can ignored data comes overall protocol. analysis starts processing bam files. important remove duplicates, include sensible methods data quality control, consistent across data protocol. provide bash script easily process bam files. Please note script works identically regardless choice reference genome, choose process bam files manually, note required column names . steps use pre-processing script, please see final section end vignette titled “Pre-processing data using script”. However, data set can used long : first column gives sample IDs, read counts chromosome (excluding MT) column headers “chr1”, “chr2”,..,“chr22” “X” “Y”. example analysis simply using inbuilt example data set, loaded RChASM package using data() function.

title: Example ChASM Analysis Using Example Data
text: stage, “mixed data” uses different data generation protocols (called protocol forward), can include column titled “protocol”. included, function assume row represents data using sequencing protocol (assigns column entry “default”). Essentially, RChASM treats different protocols separate analyses anyway. input data read R data frame/tibble, ChASM run one command: runChASM(). user must decide parameters, default values calculated using large-scale simulation study can used. Nevertheless, parameters can adjusted. minSamplesPerProtocol: minimum number samples required calculate required Dirichlet distribution parameters. encourage minimum least 30 samples (per protocol), although functional minimum 23 exists estimating parameters Dirichlet prior distribution. min_reads: minimum number reads sample can used estimating Dirichlet parameters. urge caution calling karyotypes samples less 60,000 reads, makes sense use lower threshold estimating prior distribution read counts. max_reads: maximum number reads sample can used estimating Dirichlet parameters. Sometimes read counts high-coverage samples behave strangely, likely due sample reaching complexity, made worse high-coverage samples poor preservation. p_contamination: proportion samples study expect return significant contamination estimates. can found simply running favourite contamination estimator data set, seeing proportion (although consider XX+XY contamination , conservative estimate contamination perform well). show_plot: TRUE/FALSE setting decides see x-rate vs y-rate clusters used train sex chromosomal aneuploidy prior distribution. encourage user make sure see two reasonable clusters, representing XX XY. , may need adjust min_reads max_reads, may samples variability samples (although unlikely distribution three-dimensional). printMissingIDs: TRUE/FALSE setting decides see samples missing merge two aneuploidy types: sex chromosomal autosomal, just many. RChASM run data (example_data ) using one command, runChASM(), follows. function runs two separate analyses, one sex chromosomal autosomal aneuploidies, processes data, fits prior distribution, calls karyotypes. merges analyses one result, calculates required Z-scores.  runChASM() return list merged results (karyotypes), two separate autosomal (karyotypes.auto) sex chromosomal aneuploidies (karyotypes.sca), per-protocol parameters Dirichlet distributions autosomes (dirichlet.auto) sex chromosomes (dirichlet.sca), Z-scores (z.scores), well settings used analysis (minSamplesPerProtocol, min_reads, max_reads p_contamination). need never look list output functions explore results! can also see () diagnostic plot two sensible clusters XX XY data!
code: # An example of data that RChASM analyses (omitting columns for chromosomes 3 to 20). example_data %>%   dplyr::select(sample, protocol, chr1, chr2, chr21, chr22, X, Y) %>%   head() #> # A tibble: 6 × 8 #>   sample  protocol    chr1  chr2 chr21 chr22     X     Y #>   <chr>   <chr>      <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 Ind_1_1 Protocol 1  7471  7955  1151  1209  4725     5 #> 2 Ind_1_2 Protocol 1  4248  4206   631   760  2382     2 #> 3 Ind_3_1 Protocol 1  9839  9935  1487  1779  2968   235 #> 4 Ind_4_1 Protocol 1 34248 35719  5193  5707 21254    12 #> 5 Ind_5_1 Protocol 1  2306  2357   356   397  1484     1 #> 6 Ind_6_1 Protocol 1 58317 59471  8866 10206 17742  1576 example_calls <- runChASM(rawReadCountsIn = example_data)

previous_headings: Interpreting results and producing diagnostic plots
title: Example ChASM Analysis Using Example Data
text: Now run RChASM, can see samples uncommon karyotypes. passing RChASM results summary_calls() function. function simply returns individuals karyotype XX XY, karyotype trisomy 13, 18 21. can choose samples lower bound number observed reads (suggest 60,000 reads), maximum posterior probability (suggest 0.95 general, 0.99 uncommon karyotypes). can also omit samples “unusual” (.e., significant chi-squared goodness--fit statistic). However, statistic can quite sensitive, encourage users inspect statistic context z-score plot (see panel B diagnostic plots ahead). can also simply print first 10 lines (value can changed, set Inf print lines) merged karyotype calls screen using printChASM() function entire result can saved TSV (opened Excel say) using saveChASM() function, Note can save TSV sample names sorted alphabetically setting sort_by_samplename parameter TRUE follows:
code: summary_calls(inChASM = example_calls, minTotal = 6e4, minPosterior = 0.95) #> # A tibble: 3 × 10 #>   sample  unusual flags autosomal_call sca_call C_call autosomal_total sca_total #>   <chr>   <lgl>   <int> <chr>          <chr>    <chr>            <dbl>     <dbl> #> 1 Ind_71… TRUE        4 No Aneuploidy  XXX      No Si…           70688     76444 #> 2 Ind_18… FALSE       1 No Aneuploidy  XXX      No Si…          209933    225713 #> 3 Ind_25… FALSE       0 Trisomy 21     XX       No Si…          254544    268132 #> # ℹ 2 more variables: automsomal_maxP <dbl>, sca_maxP <dbl> printChASM(inChASM = example_calls, lines = 10) #> # A tibble: 222 × 11 #>    sample  protocol unusual flags autosomal_call sca_call C_call autosomal_total #>    <chr>   <chr>    <lgl>   <int> <chr>          <chr>    <chr>            <dbl> #>  1 Ind_1_1 protoco… TRUE        3 No Aneuploidy  XX       No Si…           89539 #>  2 Ind_1_2 protoco… FALSE       1 No Aneuploidy  XX       No Si…           48376 #>  3 Ind_3_1 protoco… TRUE        2 No Aneuploidy  XY       No Si…          113335 #>  4 Ind_4_1 protoco… FALSE       0 No Aneuploidy  XX       No Si…          406472 #>  5 Ind_5_1 protoco… FALSE       0 No Aneuploidy  XX       No Si…           27731 #>  6 Ind_6_1 protoco… FALSE       0 No Aneuploidy  XY       No Si…          681256 #>  7 Ind_7_2 protoco… FALSE       0 No Aneuploidy  XY       No Si…          130928 #>  8 Ind_9_1 protoco… FALSE       0 No Aneuploidy  XX       No Si…          425906 #>  9 Ind_15… protoco… FALSE       1 No Aneuploidy  XX       No Si…            3364 #> 10 Ind_17… protoco… FALSE       1 No Aneuploidy  XY       No Si…           11699 #> # ℹ 212 more rows #> # ℹ 3 more variables: sca_total <dbl>, automsomal_maxP <dbl>, sca_maxP <dbl> saveChASM(inChASM = example_calls) saveChASM(inChASM = example_calls, sort_by_samplename = TRUE)

previous_headings: Interpreting results and producing diagnostic plots
title: Example ChASM Analysis Using Example Data
text: find individual “Ind_255_1” might carry trisomy 21, can inspect generating diagnostic plot.  plot can interpreted following way: plot x-rate (proportion reads mapping X chromosome) vs y-rate (proportion reads mapping y chromosome). colour random sample samples blue (XY) red (XX) reference, denote position individuals interest using repelled label. example, can see Ind_255_1 falls within variation XX individuals (sex chromosomal karyotype indeed XX case). plot can used assessing/confirming sex chromosomal aneuploidies, assessing genetic sex. plot shows Z-score per chromosome individuals interest, compared five randomly selected individuals. can see , except chromosome 21, read counts within reasonable variability (±2 standard deviations), confirming call trisomy 21 due strange sequencing. plot shows increase/decrease proportion reads mapping chromosome, compared “average” XY individual. see approximately 48% reads mapping chromosome 21 expected, consistent extra copy chromosome 21 present (trisomy 21). also see twice many copies X chromosome basically copies Y chromosome (compared XY), consistent XX. also see (legend) Ind_255_1 produced using “protocol 1” 268,132 mapped reads.

previous_headings: Interpreting results and producing diagnostic plots
title: Example ChASM Analysis Using Example Data
text: now generate diagnostic plot individual carries sex chromosomal aneuploidy XXX. see two possible cases least 60,000 reads, investigate (note multiple IDs can given IDs input, adding many can make plot look busy).  Note : individuals sit right XX cluster, consistent XXX. Ind_185_1 one flag (chromosome 19) “unusual”, Ind_71_1 4 flags “unusual”. However, Ind_71_1 76,444 reads, z-scores just outside dashed lines. Hence, Ind_71_1 deserves careful consideration. individuals carry almost three times much chromosome X (275% 296%), virtually nothing chromosome Y (compared XY), consistent XXX. Given seemingly borderline case Ind_71_1, now consider “well-behaved” “poorly-behaved” sample might look.
code: plot_diagnostic(   IDs = c('Ind_71_1', 'Ind_185_1'),   inChASM = example_calls,   addLabels = TRUE )

previous_headings: Interpreting results and producing diagnostic plots
what: The limits of how samples can behave
title: Example ChASM Analysis Using Example Data
text: Finally, show diagnostic plot two individuals: individual read counts behave well (Ind_4_1), individual read counts behaving strangely (Ind_66_1).  note individuals appear XY karyotype, Ind_4_1 significant per-chromosome Z-scores (panel B), approximately 100% reads expect see (panel C). However, different story Ind_66_1 many Z-scores (green squares) outside dashed lines. may now good idea look reasons data generated Ind_66_1 behaved strangely!
code: plot_diagnostic(   IDs = c('Ind_4_1', 'Ind_66_1'),   inChASM = example_calls,   addLabels = TRUE )

what: Pre-processing your data using our script
title: Example ChASM Analysis Using Example Data
text: produce required input file RChASM, download use script “CHASM_input” (requires bash, perl, samtools bedtools installed). script takes input (-) text file line path bam file, (-o) name output file. also include number optional parameters fine-tuning analysis. include: (-p) Protocol name: name data generation protocol samples. samples come different protocols, suggest running script protocol separately. (-b) Bed file: bed file restricting reads regions interest. may use cases capture used. (-w) Base pair width: bed file given, allows “wiggle room” around target sites. include due fact probe design often attracts reads just site interest, also region around sites. (-q) Minimum mapping quality: minimum allowable mapping (Phred) quality score reads. default 25. (-l) Minimum read length: minimum allowable read length bp. default 35. (-N) Header flag: given, output include column names. (-h) Help: view help file. Using console, folder text file called “Input_Bams.txt”, bash script (CHASM_input) can produce data RChASM using following command. Please note run R. can read R using read.tsv() function
code: bash CHASM_input - i Input_Bams.txt - o Output_Table.tsv example_data <- readr::read_tsv('/path_to_folder/Output_Table.tsv')

what: Detection of Chromosomal Aneuploidies in Ancient DNA Studies
title: Detection of Chromosomal Aneuploidies in Ancient DNA Studies
text: RChASM: Statistically Rigorous Method Detection Chromosomal Aneuploidies Ancient DNA Studies. RChASM R implementation ChASM (Chromosomal Aneuploidy Screening Methodology): statistically rigorous Bayesian approach screening data sets autosomal sex chromosomal aneuploidies. RChASM takes input number (deduplicated) reads mapping chromosomes 1-22 X Y chromosomes, models using Dirichlet-multinomial distribution. , RChASM returns posterior probabilities sex chromosomal karyotypes (XX, XY, XXY, XYY, XXX X) full autosomal aneuploidies (trisomy 13, trisomy 18 trisomy 21). RChASM also returns two diagnostic statistics: () posterior probability addressing whether contamination XX XY may explain observed sex chromosomal aneuploidy, (ii) chi-squared statistic measuring whether observed read counts divergent underlying distribution (may represent abnormal sequencing/quality issues).

text: inChASM result full ChASM analysis (output runChASM) file full path file name place output sort_by_samplename reorder alphabetically sample names?

title: A function for saving the results of a ChASM analysis as a tsv — saveChASM
text: saves results

title: A function for saving the results of a ChASM analysis as a tsv — saveChASM
code: example_calls <- runChASM(rawReadCountsIn = example_data)  if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ saveChASM(inChASM = example_calls) } # }

title: summary_calls — summary_calls
text: Combine autosomal sex chromosomal analyses one output

title: summary_calls — summary_calls
code: summary_calls(   inChASM,   minTotal = 60000,   minPosterior = 0.95,   ignoreUnusual = FALSE,   printProtocol = FALSE )

title: summary_calls — summary_calls
text: inChASM result combining autosomal sca analyses minTotal minimum total autosomal sca analyses minPosterior minimum value maxP can take (.e. minimum posterior probability accepted) ignoreUnusual filter unusual observations? printProtocol print protocol column?

title: summary_calls — summary_calls
text: combined calls

title: summary_calls — summary_calls
code: example_calls <- runChASM(rawReadCountsIn = example_data)  summary_calls(inChASM = example_calls, minTotal = 6e4, minPosterior = 0.95) #> # A tibble: 3 × 10 #>   sample  unusual flags autosomal_call sca_call C_call autosomal_total sca_total #>   <chr>   <lgl>   <int> <chr>          <chr>    <chr>            <dbl>     <dbl> #> 1 Ind_71… TRUE        4 No Aneuploidy  XXX      No Si…           70688     76444 #> 2 Ind_18… FALSE       1 No Aneuploidy  XXX      No Si…          209933    225713 #> 3 Ind_25… FALSE       0 Trisomy 21     XX       No Si…          254544    268132 #> # ℹ 2 more variables: automsomal_maxP <dbl>, sca_maxP <dbl>
